 Grey House — Review
 

 Review: The devil’s in the details of ‘Grey House’

 Levi Holloway’s horror opened on May 30 at Broadway’s Lyceum Theatre.

llmScore.reasoning: [two-model-fallback] | Both models agree: Mixed | Claude: The text appears to be mostly website navigation/menu content with only a fragment of actual review text mentioning 'the devil's in the details,' making it impossible to determine the critic's recommendation. | Gemini: The provided text is truncated and only contains the title of the review. Without the full review, it's impossible to determine the critic's recommendation. The title suggests a potentially mixed or negative assessment, but it's not definitive.

dtliExcerpt: At times, the psychological slow burn of his new dark comedy moves at a snail's pace — lethargizing the play's momentum and stretching entire scenes beyond comprehension — but "Grey House" cracks open in its final moments. And by its end, the play accomplishes what only the best of its genre is able to: It reminds us that the scariest monster of all lives in mankind.
showScoreExcerpt: "That teasing quality, though sometimes charming — and often, if you are a scaredy-cat, a relief from the hard-core jolts — is the giveaway that 'Grey House' should not be taken too seriously, regardless of its allusions to real-world horror of the past and present." Read more

garbageTextRemoved.reason: Broadway News site navigation/menu HTML - not review content
